channel.title: 3D Scans on Luke Jaeger

item.title: Will You Shaddap, I'm Trying To Read Over Here
item.description: Another ancient artifact from Mexico City’s Museo Anthopologico, with a very contemporary vibe

item.title: IND Station Vent Stack, Brooklyn
item.description:
One of my favorite pieces of NYC street furniture. You’ll find these enigmatic objects, about 10 feet tall, near certain stations of the F, G, and A/C lines. I believe these were air vents above the token booths (remember those?), but given the footprint, I can’t imagine they moved a lot of air. At any rate, the combination of Deco-inflected geometry and 80-year patina of corrosion and graffiti just sends me.

I made this scan with an Artec Leo, unlike the rest which I did with a phone. Scanning the top section required an 8-foot ladder.

The capture process took about an hour. My assistant figured that wearing high-visibility vests and ID lanyards would allay the suspicions of any meddlesome passers-by. It worked.

item.title: Canomorphic Ceramic Pitcher, ca 200-650 CE
item.description: The Museo del Metro has a lovely display of antiquities excavated during construction of the Mexico City subway, including this pre-Hispanic pup.

item.title: Tree With Climbing Flowers, Mexico City
Taco Stand, Mexico City
item.description: Not the greatest scan, but I like the flavor.

item.title: Handmade Model of a NYC R-17 at 1:25 Scale
item.description:
This classic piece of rolling stock will be familiar to anyone who rode the New York subway prior to 1988, when the last R-17 was retired from service.

With windows opaqued by full-car graffiti and announcements reduced to distorted gibberish, passengers, dislocated from real-world reference points, often had to guess at their whereabouts by animal intuition.

Designed from memory, reference photos, and original technical drawings, each car is completely one of a kind: hand-fabricated from archival 8-ply matte board and 3D-printed nylon, and uniquely hand painted. More info here.
